Template.Monster Data: No tactic, mid HP, no gimmick

Passives.Inspiration: All allies that can hear/see the Bannerman do +1 Damage with all attacks.

Bannerman.Lore: Bannermen are support Units that don't attack, but passively increase the Damage of all monsters.
Bannerman.Behavior:
Bannermen avoid being attacked, but stay around the battlefield.
Bannermen can be any race: Goblin, Koblod, Undead, Demons, etc. Be creative!

Passives.Strength in Numbers:
Every Goblin attack deals +1 Damage for each Goblin fighting in their squad.
So, even if a goblin is alone, it has +1.
When a Goblin dies or flees, it no longer counts as a fighting Goblin.

Goblin.Lore: Goblins are Small Units that deal more damage the more Goblins there are. In large numbers, they can be devastating even to high-Level parties.
Goblin.Behavior:
Attack random targets.
Be careful! Too many goblins can easily overwhelm the party, even if the encounter is balanced with Experience!
When a Goblin dies or flees, describe that their team loses momentum.
Goblin.Pair:
Pair with 1 Boar (Giant), 1 Bannerman.
For an intense battle, pair with an Ogre.

Abilities.Healing Light: Heal a non-Acolyte Unit for 8. All Units around it become Blinded.

Passives.Holy Spells: Acolytes can also cast other small utility spells, like making light or purifying water.

Acolyte.Lore: Acolytes are support healer Units that inflict Blindness.
Acolyte.Behavior:
Heals the lowest Health ally. If attacked melee, uses Weapon.
Use as support for Guards, etc.
Acolyte.Monster Data: No tactic, mid HP, no gimmick

Eldritch Blast (spell).Decaying: Target takes +1 Scourge Damage for the rest of combat (after the attack). Stacks infinitely.

Cultist.Behavior:
Stay at range and shoot Eldritch Blast.
Small time Cultists might surrender when they realize they are being overwhelmed.
Cultist.Pair: Pair with melee monsters like Skeletons, Bandits or Guards to tank for them.
Cultist.Lore:
Cultists are weak ranged damage Units.

Often, people join a Cult for the sense of community and for small boons like improved health, knowledge, wealth and basic spellcasting.
Not all Cultists are evil; some are simply misguided or drawn in by friends or family, and they they can't get out.
Cultist.Monster Data: No tactic, mid HP, no gimmick
Cultist.Story Ideas:
A Cultist might snitch on her "family" and wants out of the Cult, but she can't without risking her life.
She needs the help of the Players.
But to do so, the Players must infiltrate the Cult or help her find out more about their leader.
They will need to kill the local leader; thus, a friendship might be made with the ex-Cultist.

Weapon.No Remorse: Deal +50% melee Damage against targets affected by any Crowd Control

Opportunity Attack.Effect: When a Unit exist the melee range of a Kobold, attack it with the weapon.

Passives.Sidestep: The first time a Koblod would be affected by a negative thing in Combat, if it makes sense, it is sidestepped and completely negated (unless it's a mind spell, or is unavoidable like Heat Metal; apply common sense; if in doubt, assume it's unavoidable).

Passives.Trap Knowledge: Can automatically avoid traps laid by them and have +5 to detecting traps.

Koblod.Lore: Kobolds are annoying rascals that always dodge the first attack on them.
Koblod.Behavior:
Koblods run away after they finish attacking if they can.
Koblods prefer to ambush adventurers and fight in the dark.
Koblod.Pair:
Pair with Bannermen, Camazots.
For stronger encounters, Koblods might ride on Rust Roaches.

Net.Effect: Target must roll a Dexterity Check at least 10 or be Rooted.

Passives.Water Healing (group): At the end of every Round, all Morlocs heal for 10 Health if in water (even shallow water).

Passives.Fast Swimmers: Can move 2 meters for each 1 meter spent for movement in water.

Passives.Paddle Feet: Immune to difficult terrain and caltrops (except wind).

Morloc.Lore: Morlocs are frog or fish people who heal if in water and prevent their prey from running.
Morloc.Behavior:
Uses Net on the first round if possible.
Attack random targets and prefer to fight in water, but will chase outside of water too. They're not smart enough to always use water to their advantage.
Suggested Obstacles: Net Trap (10 Grade Dexterity Check, Root)
Shallow Water (Difficult Terrain) (Make sure you have land with no water as well, so player can prevent their Water Healing)
Morloc.Monster Data: No tactic, mid HP, no gimmick
Morloc.Story Ideas: The morlocs might have migrated closer to civilization because their original habitat was taken over by resource-greedy humans or a dangerous monster.

1H Weapon.Kick: If rolled at least one 1, target must pass a Dexterity Check at least 10 or have 4d10 Gold stolen and become Slowed.

Bandit.Behavior:
Tries to ambush and steal. If they steal something, they run away.
They might have 1 extra bandit whose only goal is to sneakily steal things and does not attack.
Attacks the closest target.
Bandit.Monster Data: No tactic, mid HP, no gimmick
Bandit.Story Ideas:
There could be Bandits that only steal from the rich to distribute to the poor.
They might also be people who turned to bandits because they opposed the current political regime and all their property was taken away.
They could be secretly employed by the mayor to bring him riches.

Abilities.Darkness (Free): At the end of first turn, create a 5x5 meter area of Magical Darkness centered on Drough. This provides Cover to all Units inside against all attacks. The darkness remains there for 1 minute.

Passives.Acrobatic: Can easily jump up to 3 meters.

Passives.Magical Darkvision: Can see in the dark and in magical darkness.

Drough.Behavior:
On their first turn, they create a magical darkness area.
They try to remain in the darkness.
Drough.Pair:
For a more magical fight, pair with 1 Acolyte, Flying Weapons.
For a more physical fight, pair with Camazots, Bat Swarms.
Suggested Obstacles: Magical Barriers that act as simple obstacles
Drough.Monster Data: No tactic, mid HP, no gimmick

Attack.Effect: Deal 1d6 + 1 Smash Damage to a Unit and push it a number of meters equal to the die rolled.
Attack.Notes: If the Unit would fall down more than 2 meters, it instead grabs the nearest ledge and can climb it with a Half-Action (on its turn).

Hurl Object.Effect: Throw something nearby into a Unit for 1d6 Damage. If it has obstacle Cover, the obstacle breaks; otherwise, the Unit becomes Dazed.

Abilities.Stomp: Damage all Units within 2 meters for 4 Pulse Damage (or 2d4 - 1).

Ogre.Behavior:
Ogres will attack whatever is convenient.
Throw rocks at the party's back line.
An Ogre might also choose to throw (Slam: Throw) one of its allies without dealing the base Damage!
Ogre.Lore:
A common question regarding Ogres is: if they are so large, what do they eat?
Ogres can eat stones, tree bark, bones, even dirt, but they'll always eat meat if given the option.
Ogre.Monster Data: No tactic, mid HP, no gimmick

Bite (*).Gnoll Fever: If Bite dealt Damage, the target can't spend Mana on its next turn.

Passives.Blood Rush:
As soon as the Gnoll drops to/below 50% HP, it can move up to 5 meters and make a Bite attack (even during other Units' turns).
Then, the other Unit can continue its turn.
From then on, the Gnoll can make 2 Bite attacks per turn.

Gnoll.Behavior:
When dropping to 50% HP, they can run towards the back line of the party and bite them!
If healthy, Gnolls employ tactics like kiting, flanking, etc.
If below 50% HP, Gnolls go wild!
Gnoll.Monster Data: No tactic, mid HP, no gimmick

Melee.Shield Bash: If rolled at least one 1, target must roll a Might Check at least 10 or be Cripled.

Volley of Arrows.Effect:
ALL ranged Guards target a 4x4 area.
All Units there take 1d4 Pierce Damage for each ranged Guard.

Guard.Behavior:
Attack the closest enemy to them.
A large group of ranged Guards can be devastating to players huddled together.
Try to split them half ranged, half melee.
Guard.Pair: Pair with 1 Bannerman, Hounds, 1 or 2 Acolytes.
Guard.Monster Data: No tactic, mid HP, no gimmick

Abilities.Copy Spell: Once per combat, for 1 Action, the Hobgoblin can cast a Spell another player has cast (with that player's exact stats).

Passives.Bold in Numbers: Has +1 Defense for each other alive ally on its team.

Hobgoblin.Behavior:
Hobgoblins fight with its allies.
Will wait for a good moment to use Copy Spell.
Be careful how many enemies are in an encounter with a Hobgoblin! Too many enemies can turn a regular encounter into a deadly one!
Players should know Hobgoblins can copy a spell.
Every time an ally of the Hobgoblin dies, describe how the Hobgoblin appears less bold (aka loses Defense).
Hobgoblin.Pair: Pair with Goblins, Wolves, even an Ogre.
Hobgoblin.Suggested Obstacles: None! Hobgoblins don't like traps (but its allies do)!
Hobgoblin.Monster Data: Kill me last, careful with spells

Passives.RAGE: Whenever an Orc takes Damage, it gains +1 Damage on all melee attacks.

Orc.Behavior: Orcs prefer melee combat. Try to put more Melee orcs than Ranged.
Orc.Pair: Pair with Goblins, Wolves or even Ogres.
Orc.Monster Data: Kill us 1 by 1 and with big hits

Hollow Touch (5m).Anticoagulate: Target can not cast healing Abilities on its next turn.

Abilities.Pain Tether (free) (once per combat):
Choose a target the Cult Hierarch can see.
Until the combat is over, that target instanty takes half of all Damage the Cult Hierarch takes.
Only one Unit can be Pain Tethered to only one Cult Hierarch.
Concentration (interrupt it with any CC except Slows).

Abilities.Counterspell (free) (once per combat) (R:
When a Unit casts a spell, it must succeed a 11 Grade Sense Check or the spell is cancelled and the action lost, but not the Mana.
If it succeeds, then the spell can't be Counterspelled again (e.g. from another Cult Hierarch).

Passives.Basic Magic: Can cast small non-combat utility spells like Magic Tricks, Light, etc

Cult Hierarch.Behavior:
The goal of a Cult Hierarch in combat is not to kill, but inflict Damage long term for the Players' mission.
Will cast Inflict Wounds on different targets to stall their progress in the current adventure.
When the combat starts, cast Pain Tether on a Unit. Each Cult Hierarch casts Pain Tether on a different target.
Cast Counterspell on first occasion. Multiple Cult Hierarchs will NOT cast Counterspell at the same time or to try again.
Cult Hierarch.Monster Data: No tactic, mid HP, no gimmick
Cult Hierarch.Story Ideas:
Cult Hierarchs should be among the first or mid-way through a dungeon-delve or mission, as they inflict Damage that can not be healed.
Players might hear reports of mutilated cows or other animals - no blood, and perfectly removed organs.
Yes, it's a cult.

Roots (Human) (10m).Root: The target must succeed a 11 Might Check or be Rooted.

Maul (Owlbear).Daze: If rolled at least one 6 or 1, the target must succeed a 12 Might Check or be Dazed.

Tongue Grab (Toad).Pull: If rolled at least one 6 or 1, the target must succeed a 12 Might Check or be Crippled, Slowed and pulled next to the Toad Druid.

Abilities.Shapeshift (free): Every turn, the Druid can transform into either an Owlbear, Giant Toad or Giant Eagle. It uses a different attack or has a different Passive for each form.

Passives.Barkskin (Human) (Reaction): Defense becomes 5 until start of its next turn.

Passives.Owl Screech (Owlbear): Once per round, after an enemy casts a spell, all Units that can hear the Owlbear Druid must succeed a 12 Sense Check or be Silenced.

Passives.Toxins (Toad): Whenever the Toad is Melee attacked, the attacker takes 3 Poison Damage.

Passives.Druidcraft (Non-Combat): Can cast small, non-combat utility Spells like DruiGraderaft, Light, etc. Can also shapeshift into other non-combat animals, like bugs, fish, etc.

Druid.Behavior:
Will shapeshift into whatever is better in that situation.
Use Owlbear against casters and melee.
Use Toad against ranged attackers.
Use Eagle to escape or against low-armored foes.
Druid.Pair: Pair with Twig Blights, Wild Fungus, Dryads, Fairy Dragons, Hippogriffs, Wolves or any other animals you see fit.
Druid.Lore:
Druids are versatile and flexible enemies.
Generally, they are not evil and respect nature.
Feel free to have druids that live in any sort of environment, like deserts, mountain tops, tundras, etc.
Change their animals to match animals native to that environment.
Druid.Monster Data: No tactic, mid HP, no gimmick
Druid.Story Ideas:
An encounter idea is that a druid circle attempts to summon a fey being (a sort of magical forest creature from another dimension).
Their intentions are pure, but they don't know they are being tricked into actually summoning a fiend.
The players know the true identity of the fey.
Will they stop the druids peacefully?

Plant Attack.Plant Reach:
Instead of the Dryad attacking, she makes a nearby (15 meters) plant attack.
A plant attack has 3 meters range from the plant.
E.g. a tree slams with its branches, a bush shoots thorns, etc

Abilities.Sleep Spores (free) (5m range to edge):
Choose a 2x2 meter area.
It becomes Difficult Terrain.
Any Unit ending their turn in Spores must succeed a 11 Sense Check or it falls Asleep and its initiative becomes 0.
The Dryad casts Sleep Spores every turn before Plant Attack.

Passives.Treesposition: Instead of moving normally, the Drayd can touch a tree and teleport near another tree within 10 meters (if not Silenced).

Passives.Immunities: Immune to Poison Damage and Sleep.

Passives.Tree Bound (Non-Combat): Every Dryad is permanently bound to a tree. If that tree dies, the Dryad dies. Dryads keep their home tree secret and can't wander more than a few kilometers away without dying.

Dryad.Behavior:
Dryads might attack the players from a very long range if she deems them a threat.
She will stay hidden. The players might make a Check for seeing the Dryad. The recommended pass is 10 + the number of meters to the Dryad.
If her home is threatened, she will fight to the death.
Otherwise, she might run away when low HP.
Dryad.Pair: Pair with Wild Fungus or a Fairy Dragon.
Dryad.Monster Data: No tactic, mid HP, no gimmick
Dryad.Story Ideas:
Players might hear a rumor about a place in the forest where there are forbidden Fruit of Knowledge trees. 
Eating such a fruit will make the player Skilled in anything knowledge-related.
The Dryads, though, forbid the players from eating them, because the fruits are their children (literally).
Will they leave, fight the Dryads or sneakily steal the fruit (of course, the Dryads know they are trying to sneak and will ambush the Players).

Naga.Speed: 4 on land, 6 in water and shallow water

Warrior - Melee Weapon (2m).Chains: If rolled at least one 6 or 1, the target must succeed a 11 Might Check or be pulled to a solid object within 3 meters and be Rooted.

Warrior - Harpoon (5m).Pull: If rolled at least one 6, the target must succeed a 11 Might Check or be pulled to the Naga and be Slowed.

Abilities.Mage - Enslave Magic (free) (once per co: Gain control of a non-sentient summoned Unit until combat ends. If the creature is sentient, it must succeed a 12 Sense Check or be enslaved. It always takes its turn after the Naga, even if it already had its turn. Effect ends after 1 minute or if this Naga dies.

Passives.Mages and Warriors: A Naga is either a Mage or a Warrior. A Mage can only use [Mage] Abilities. A Warrior can only use [Warrior] Abilities.

Naga.Behavior:
Warrior: Use Melee Weapon attacks if the Naga can. If it can't get in range to attack, use Harpoon.
Mage: Always use Enslave Magic on Units that players summon (e.g. spirit weapons, demons, etc).
Naga.Pair: Pair with enslaved Morlocs, Crabs (Giant), a Bannerman.
Naga.Lore:
Naga are known to enslave other species, like Morlocs.
Some of them can cast water magic and take over control of summoned creatures.
They can hold their breath long enough to stay on land a few hours at a time.
They communicate through vibrations in the water, so their language might be inaudible in the open air.
Although intelligent and resembling people, they are still monsters and have an innate instinct to kill everything they can't enslave.
Naga.Story Ideas:
Here's an encounter idea: a camp of Morlocs is expanding and getting too close to a village.
When they get there, the players find out that some Naga have enslaved them and are hiding in a nearby cove.
Naga.Valuable Loot: Nagas might carry pearls worth 20g each

Melee Weapon.Onset: +1 Damage for each meter moved towards the target (strafing around the target does not count, it has to be straight movement towards it; diagonals are valid if you play on a grid).

Abilities.Back Hooves (free) (usable only before m: A target must succeed a 11 Grade Dexterity Check or it takes 1d8 Smash Damage and is Dazed.

Passives.Moving Target: If the Centaur moved this round, its Defense is doubled for the rest of the round.

Passives.Hooves: Immune to Caltrops and Difficult Terrain.

Passives.Jumpers: Can freely jump up to 2 meters high (even while moving)

Centaur.Behavior:
Moving towards the target, then switching direction, then moving towards it again only counts the meters AFTER switching direction as moving towards it.
Centaur move as much as they possibly can to maximize their Onset Damage.
If there is only one enemy around it, it will use Back Hooves. If it Dazes the target, it will move towards another target.
If there are multiple enemies around it, will use Back Hooves and attack the other.
Centaur strive when they are high on the Initiative track, as any attacks made against them before they take their turn deals more Damage (due to Moving Target).
Snaring a Centaur is very effective.
Centaur.Pair: Pair with Wolves reskinned as Hyenas.
Centaur.Lore:
Centaurs live in glades, savannas and even mountain tops.
They often settle near water and between hills to isolate their tribe from any potential danger.
Centaurs are ferocious and brutal if you challenge them.
They are also territorial and like to expand their territory through sheer violence.
They are also stoic, loyal and can appear very noble if given the chance to talk to.
Centaur.Monster Data: No tactic, mid HP, no gimmick
Centaur.Story Ideas:
If you need an encounter idea, a camp of adventurers might need help defending against a Centaur attack in a few hours.
Turns out, Centaurs were way ahead and attack just 30 minutes later.
Centaurs do the best when they are the ones attacking and ambushing.
Valuable Loot: Leather Pelt* (20g) - low quality, but does the job

Passives.Necromantic Control: When in a group with other undead Unit(s), one undead is bond to this necromancer. When this necromancer dies, that undead dies as well.

Necromancer.Behavior: Avoids damage and sits in the back
Necromancer.Monster Data: No tactic, mid HP, no gimmick

Passives.Optionally Flying: If it makes sense for the bug to fly, it can fly.

Bug (Giant).Behavior:
Keep them coming!
If the players attack a bug nest, keep sending Bugs onto them every round!
A nest contains dozens if not hundreds of them!
The goal of the players should be to get rid of the nest, unless they really want to kill off about 100 of these bugs.
See how the players deal with 15 of these at once in a fight.
Bug (Giant).Lore:
Giant Bugs can be any type of bug: cockroack, wasp, ant, etc. Be creative!
Their nests usually have hundreds of them. Check the Behavior panel for some really creative fights!
Bug (Giant).Monster Data: No tactic, mid HP, no gimmick

Bite (3m).Maining: If rolled 3 or 4, target becomes Slowed.

Hound.Behavior:
Try to reach the back line and chase them to death.
Add to encounters with Bandits, Guards, Cultists, etc.
Hound.Lore: Hounds can be alive, undead or demon hounds (Hell Hounds).
Hound.Monster Data: No tactic, mid HP, no gimmick

Facehug.Attach: Target becomes Blinded until the Camazot is killed. The Camazot remains attached to the target and moves with it.

Passives.Echolocation: Can see in the dark and is immune to Blinding.

Camazot.Behavior: Each Camazot attacks a different target and chases them to death.
Camazot.Pair: Pair with Koblods and other dark monsters.
Camazot.Monster Data: No tactic, mid HP, no gimmick

Wolf.Behavior:
Not afraid to run straight through the front line to reach the back line.
Wolves try to attack each party member equally.
Not usually drawn towards the tanks.
Make it a Dire Wolf by increasing Experience to 150, Health to 39 and Damage to 8 (or 2d4 + 3).
Wolf.Monster Data: No tactic, mid HP, no gimmick

Passives.Swarmy: Takes double Damage from Area Abilities.

Bat Swarm.Behavior: Swarms try to stay near eachother and don't spread too much.
Bat Swarm.Variants: Rat Swarm, Raven Swarm, Insect Swarm

Passives.Thick Chitin: Takes -50% Pierce and Slash Damage (after Defense).

Passives.Updive: Crabs might sit under mud or sand. If a Unit is right on top of them, they can use all their movement to get up and directly make them Fumbling.

Crab (Giant).Behavior:
No other specific behavior, it's just a crab.
Players will have trouble breaking through their shell.
Crab (Giant).Monster Data: No tactic, low HP, no gimmick

Passives.3rd Round Frenzy: On the 3rd round of combat, all rats become enraged and gain +1d4 Damage on all attacks and +3 Speed.

Passives.Immunities: Immune to Poison, Slows and Fumbling.

Rat (Giant).Behavior:
Will ignore front lines and go straight for the back line of the party.
But if in range, attack random targets.
Rat (Giant).Monster Data: No tactic, mid HP, no gimmick

Passives.Armor Breakers: Attacks ignore Defense, Protection and Shielding and immediately break all Protection and Shielding on the target.

Passives.Jumpers: Can freely jump up to 2 meters high.

Raptor.Behavior: Prefers to attack heavily armored enemies.
Raptor.Monster Data: No tactic, mid HP, no gimmick

Fangs.Spider Effects:
On 6, target must succeed an 11 Grade Might Check or be Crippled.
On 1, target becomes Poisoned until cured - takes 1d4 Poison Damage every 6 hours. A Unit can't be Poisoned multiple times.

Coccoon (once) (3m).Effect: Target must succeed a 10 Dexterity Check or be Rooted.

Abilities.Web Wall (free) (once): Create a 3x3, thin wall or area of Web with 20 HP, 0 Defense. It takes 200% Fire Damage. If it's on the ground, it's Hard Terrain for non-spiders.

Passives.Spider Climb: Can freely walk on walls and on web

Spider (Giant).Behavior:
One spider uses its action to block off an exit with Web Wall.
Spiders attack random targets.
The spiders are listed as Insects for ease of navigation.
Suggested Obstacles: Spider Web (Difficult Terrain) all over the place
Spider (Giant).Monster Data: No tactic, mid HP, no gimmick
Spider (Giant).Variants: Ettercap, Centipede (Giant) - Doesn't have any Web-related abilities, but also casts Crippling Poison when it rolls 1.

Bear.Behavior: Use this as a standard Large animal.
Bear.Monster Data: No tactic, mid HP, no gimmick
Bear.Variants: Any other similar animal (e.g. giant badger)

Abilities.Glittering Breath (2m to edge):
Target a 3x3 meter area and attack all Units there for 2d6 - 1.
For each 1 or 6, Units that took Damage must succeed a 11 Sense Check or fall Asleep.

Passives.Antimagic: Takes -50% Damage from Spells of any kind.

Pegasus.Behavior:
Pegasi aren't keen on combat, but if they decide to fight, they excel against Spell casters.
Will fly away if in too much danger.
Pegasus.Lore:
Pegasi are winged horses that keep themselves pristine by means of magic.
A Pegasus can put targets to sleep.
Pegasus.Monster Data: No tactic, mid HP, no gimmick

Abilities.Stone Glare (5m range): Target makes a 11 Grade Sense Check or it takes 1d8 Damage and is Crippled or Silenced (cockatrice chooses).

Abilities.Tail Sweep (2m range):
Target and all Units 1 meter from it make a 11 Grade Dexterity Check.
On fail, they take 9 Smash Damage and are Fumbling (or 2d4 + 5).
On success, they take half of that Damage.

Passives.Bloody Shriek:
When dropping below 50% HP, Cockatrice shrieks.
All Units within 6 meters must succeed a 11 Grade Sense Check or be Dazed and take 1d8 Psychic Damage.

Cockatrice.Behavior:
Every turn, the Cockatrice jumps to attack a different target.
Can be paired with a couple of Axe Beaks as part of its pack, or you can treat them as its offspring.
Cockatrice.Monster Data: No tactic, mid HP, no gimmick

Tusks.Charge Attack:
If Boar moved at least 4 meters straight and then attacked, the target makes a 12 Grade Might Check.
If it fails, it takes 1d4 Pierce Damage and is pushed 2 meters in any direction (boar chooses).

Boar (Dire).Behavior:
Charges in a straight line and attacks with tusks.
Can be a good extra for Orcs, Goblins, Gnolls, etc.
Suggested Obstacles: Fallen trees (require Dex check to jump)
Boar (Dire).Monster Data: No tactic, mid HP, no gimmick

Envelop.Facehug:
If it did Damage, the Stalacmantle remains attached to the target until the end of the target's turn (therefore, the target is in Darkness - has Cover; see Darkray's Passive Ability).
If the Unit underneath moves, the Stalacmantle makes a Dexterity Check. If it succeeds, it moves with the target until the end of its turn (unless it teleports).

Passives.Magic Absorption: Absorbs (cancels) the first Spell targeting it (the Actions used for it are lost) (apply common sense - Focus Fling is not absorbed).

Passives.Artificial Darkness: Emmits a beam of Magical Darkness right underneath it (provides Cover).

Passives.Camouflage (Non-Combat): Indistinguishable from a stalagmite or stalactite.

Stalacmantle.Behavior:
Hides in plain sight and ambushes their prey.
Each Stalacmantle flies and targets one enemy.
Stalacmantle.Story Ideas: Have a swarm of Darkmantles directly at the entrance to a cave. Players won't expect it!

Acid Spit (3m range).Corrode:
Ignores Defense.
If rolled at least one 1 or 4, target must make a 12 Grade Might Check.
If it fails:
- Loses 5d10 gold (the coins corrode)
- A metal weapon loses 1 Damage permanently
- A metal armor loses 1 Defense permanently
- A metal item in their inventory corrodes

Passives.Upside: Takes -50% Pierce, Poison and Acid Damage.

Rust Roach.Lore:
Rust Roaches consume minerals such as calcium and iron.
A lot of their meals are rocks or dirt high in minerals.
They will never say no to pure iron, gold or steel, though!
Rust Roach.Monster Data: No tactic, mid HP, no gimmick

Abilities.Sleepless Dive: Attack a Unit for Slash/Pierce/Poison Damage equal to half the number of hours it has been awake.

Passives.Tiring Presence: Every round passing in combat counts as 2 hours of sleeplessness. Apply Exhaustion rules if necessary.

Passives.Flier: Flies. Can freely Break its Movement.

Phantrance.Monster Data: No tactic, mid HP, no gimmick

Passives.Hot Touch:
When a Unit melee attacks the Fire Snake with weapon, it takes 3 Fire Damage.
It must succeed a 12 Might Check or drop the weapon.
It can use a Half-Action to pick it up on its turn.

Fire Snake.Lore:
The Snake is just a generic animal that can be a fire spirit.
Feel free to substitute any animal for the Snake.
Also, feel free to substitute any element for Fire.
Fire Snake.Monster Data: No tactic, mid HP, no gimmick
Fire Snake.Variants: Fire Fox, Frost Wolf, Thunder Serpent

Abilities.Blink: All Units within 2 meters make a Grade 12 Sense Check or become Blinded. Then teleport up to 5 meters.

Abilities.Force Wall (15 meters): Create transparent magical screen (3m tall, 5m wide) that nothing can pass through, except Magic Bolts. The screen has 7 HP and 7 Defense.

Passives.Absorb Magic: Whenever a non-Fairy Dragon casts a spell in combat, the Fairy Dragon gains +1 Damage with all Spells and attacks until the combat is over.

Passives.Resistances: Takes -50% Fire, Cold, Pulse and Shock Damage.

Passives.Basic Magic (Non-Combat): Fairy Dragons can also cast minor utility spells out of combat, like creating minor illusions, turning invisible out of combat, etc.

Fairy Dragon.Behavior:
Fairy Dragons avoid melee combat.
They prefer to spread their Magic Bolts on the physical fighters of the team.
Use Force Wall to block off or split party members.
Fairy Dragons usually live in pairs of 2 (couples).
Fairy Dragon.Lore:
Fairy Dragons like to use magic for fun.
A Fairy Dragon is about the size of a large dog, but very resilient given their magical nature.
Fairy Dragon.Story Ideas:
If you need an idea for an encounter, players are told a whole area is closed off with impenetrable Force Walls, but the players can find a way in through a cave.
Turns out the Fairy Dragons put those walls to protect themselves from poachers (who, unsurprisingly, told the players to go after the force walls).
If the players turn on the poachers, it turns out they also own a pet Fairy Dragon that will fight with them.

Beak/Claws/Wings.Push: Each attack that did Damage pushes the target 1 meter. Target takes 1 extra Damage if it collided with something or had no space to be pushed.

Passives.Flyby Prone: When it enters the vecinity (1m) of a person, it must succeed a 11 Might Check or be Fumbling.

Hippogriff.Behavior:
Hippogriffs are smart enough to try to corner or push people off ledges with their attacks.
They will fly even to the back line to try to push them off a cliff or into a corner.
Hippogriffs like to ambush prey especially when it's raining or during a thunderstorm, as the rain camouflages their presence.
Hippogriff.Lore:
Hippogriffs are notoriously agressive and almost exclusively carnivorous.
To find prey, a Hippogriff will circle in the sky around an area until it finds something suitable for eating.
Hippogriffs often migrate long distances to find a mate, as they avoid interbreeding.
It might not be that uncommon to see a flying hippogriff in the sky during the day.
Hippogriffs adapt very quickly to new environments. Thus you might find a hippogriff in a forest, on a snow covered mountain, on an island beach hunting for fish, etc.
Suggested Obstacles: Ruin walls, or lots of larger wall-like debris
Hippogriff.Monster Data: No tactic, mid HP, no gimmick
Hippogriff.Story Ideas:
When it's raining and the players say "It couldn't be any worse", introduce them to a few Hippogriffs.
It can also be very atmospheric if it's raining both in real life and in-game. That's the perfect moment to introduce Hippogriffs!

Red Attack (Soldier).Ram: If rolled at least one 4, target is either Rooted, or it takes an extra 1d4 Damage (its choice).

Blue Attack (5m) (Mage).Bile: All Units within 2 meters of target take half of the Damage taken by the main target.

Abilities.Yellow Attack (2m) (Worker):
Attack all Units within 2 meters of the Antheir for 1d6 + 3.
All Units hit become Fumbling.

Passives.Chitinous Shell:
Can only take up to 10 Damage at a time (from an attack, a missile, etc; multi-hit spells count as multiple times, such as Magic Missiles).
Exception: Psychic and Scourge Damage.

Passives.Different Roles:
Antheirs have different colors, and thus different roles.
Assign a different color to each Antheir from Red, Blue and Yellow (randomly or by choice).
It can only use that type of Action.

Antheir.Behavior:
Red Antheirs, Soldiers, rush into battle and fight to death!
Yellow Antheirs, Workers, position themselves between as many enemies as possible.
Blue Antheirs, Mages, stay far away and shoot their bile. They might stay attached to walls or hide behind terrain.
Antheir.Pair: Pair with Bugs (Giant) reskinned as Baby Antheirs.
Antheir.Lore:
Antheirs are large crusty ants that fill various roles in their small societies.
While not numerous, they are intelligent for an animal, although hard to train.
Antheirs always live with their tribes and usually do not stray far away from the nest.
Suggested Obstacles: Antheir Eggs (that spawn Bugs (Giant) when destroyed)
Antheir.Monster Data: No tactic, mid HP, no gimmick
Antheir.Story Ideas:
Deep within the rural area of a kingdom, a village has an unwritten "pact" with a tribe of Antheirs.
Villages don't enter Antheir territory, and Antheirs don't enter village territory.
This proves difficult when the Players must traverse the Antheir domain to reach their destination.
Will they go around or risk a battle with the Antheirs?
Valuable Loot: Chitinous Carapace (20g) can be used for as temporary plating
Vial of Acid (25g); this should require a Check, and the Player takes Acid Damage on a failed Check

Abilities.Breath (Fire) (5m): Attack the target and all Units 2 meters from it for 8 Fire Damage (or 2d6 + 1).

Abilities.Breath (Cold): Attack all targets in a 6x1 meter line for 8 Cold Damage (or 2d6 + 1).

Breath (Shock) (5m).Chain Lightning: Hits the main target, another target within 3 meters of the main target and another target within 3 meters of the secondary target (against Defense).

Passives.Elemental: A Dragon Whelp has one element (Fire, Cold, Shock, etc). Its Breath attack depends on its type. If your preferred element isn't here, just change one of the Breath attacks to match your element.

Passives.Elemental Resistance: Takes -50% Damage from its elemental type.

Dragon Whelp.Behavior: Keeps a distance and attacks while it's flying.
Dragon Whelp.Lore:
Although considered a Whelp, these dragons are about the size of a small horse.
Dragon Whelps are not mature enough to speak (usually), but can understand language (draconic and/or common).
Suggested Obstacles: Water (that conducts electricity or can freeze)
Dragon Whelp.Monster Data: No tactic, mid HP, no gimmick
Dragon Whelp.Variants: Fairy Dragon Whelp (its element is Pulse and takes -50% Fire, Cold, Shock and Pulse Damage).

Ripping Bite (2m).Bite Off: If this attack did at least 10 Damage, the Tyrannosaurus permanently bites off an arm of a leg (of target's choice). The target gets a Missing Arm or Missing Leg Feat.
Ripping Bite (2m).Upgrade: Can only be used on the first Turn every Round.
Ripping Bite (2m).Notes: Can't leave a target with less than 1 arm and 1 leg.

Abilities.Slam (1m to edge): Damage all Units in a 3x3 area for 2d8. If any of them is Large or larger, it becomes Dazed.

Heroics.Terrifying Roar (Round 2): Roar - all Units that can hear it must roll a Sense Check at least 11 or become Feared and Silenced.

Heroics.Tyrant King (Round 4): The Tyrannosaurus is enraged, and can now repeat Abilities (e.g. use Ripping Bite on both turns).

Tyrannosaurus.Monster Data: No tactic, mid HP, no gimmick
Tyrannosaurus.Valuable Loot: 1d8 intact T-Rex fangs worth 30g each, 1d4 intact T-Rex bones worth 25g each, T-Rex hide which is a rare valuable material worth 100g.

Beak/Claws.Damage: Make 5 attacks for 1d4 Pierce or Slash (of choice)
Beak/Claws.Defense Break: Every rolled 4 or 1 puts one Stunful token on the target. At 3 Stunful tokens, the target must succeed a Grade 11 Might Check or be Stunned (then remove the tokens).

Passives.Overwhelm:
Once per turn, the Griphon can try to move on the space of another Unit.
That Unit must succeed a 12 Might Check or be Rooted and Fumbling.
It remains Rooted and Fumbling as long as the Griphon is on top of it.

Griphon.Behavior:
Griphons will fly above the battlefield and descend down to Overwhelm a target.
If it succeeds, it proceeds to ravage at it with its 5 Beak/Claws attacks.
Do not pair with Hippogriffs, as Griphons are the natural enemies of Hippogriffs in the wilds.
Griphon.Lore:
Griphons are majestic creature with the front body and wings of an eagle, and rear body of a lion.
Often, Griphons represent royalty and are among the more expensive mounts and pets, though they can be Trained and are very loyal once domesticated.
Griphons are said to be the kings of the skies and they are apex predators of the wilds.
Riding a Griphon is a privilege - very few get the chance to do it. Being allowed to ride it is a sign of utmost respect from the Griphon.
Griphons hunt wild game and are known to venture closer to human habitats during poor hunting seasons.
If they come into human territory, they can wreak havoc by eating horses and livestock.
Griphon.Monster Data: No tactic, mid HP, no gimmick
Griphon.Story Ideas:
One fun way for the players to interact with a Griphon is to see her flying in the skies, but not being able to get to her.
If the players chase her, the Griphon will realize she is being chased and will lead the players straight into other dangers or even to her nest, where she will fight them on her own ground, with her partner Griphon.
Griphon.Valuable Loot: A Griphon head might prove a valuable trophy to be sold to collectors (50g). 1d4 of its feathers can also be collected as special feathers, worth 25g each.

Abilities.Claws/Bite/Tail:
4 Damage (Slash/Pierce/Smash).
Breaks all Large or smaller obstacles within 1 meter of the target.

Abilities.Roar: All enemies that can hear the Behemoth take 3 Psychic Damage that ignores Defense.

Abilities.Throw Boulder (5m): 7 Damage (Smash). Target must succeed a Grade 12 Might Check or be Dazed or Rooted (its choice). This takes 2 turns.

Abilities.Destroy (Last) (10m): Leap towards the (an) enemy that took the least Damage this round. They must succeed a Grade 12 Might Check, or take 2d6 Damage and be Stunned.

Passives.Nine Hide Layers: All Damage received is rounded down to a multiple of 9 (e.g. 13 becomes 9, 7 becomes 0, 47 becomes 45).

Passives.Ground Smashing:
At 66% Health, the Behemoth immediately (or as soon as possible) stomps the ground. All Units around must make a Grade 12 Might Check or be flung 6 meters up in the air and take 5 Damage (otherwise just 3 meters and no Damage).
From then on, Throw Boulder no longer takes 2 turns.

Passives.Berserking: At 33% Health, the Behemoth goes berserking. All Damage it deals AND takes is doubled.

Behemoth.Monster Data: No tactic, mid HP, no gimmick

Abilities.Fire Ball (10m to edge): Deals 9 Damage in a 4x4 area (or 3d4 + 1). The area stays lit with dragon fire. Spawns an elemental (20, attacks for 1d6 (3m)).

Abilities.Fiery Flight: Fly up to 6 meters, knocking everyone away and dealing 8 Damage. Leaves dragon fire on the ground.

Abilities.Flame Away (3m): Target must succeed a Might Check or be pushed indefinitely. Takes 1 Pulse Damage for each 1 meter pushed.

Abilities.Land Mines: Spawn 3 land mines near players that explode for 1d8 + 2 Damage when hit by fire. Will not spawn mines directly in fire. When mines explode, they summon a small Fire Elemental (20 Health, attacks for 1d6 (3m)).

Passives.Chromatic: At the end of its every turn, it must change its element to one of Fire, Poison, Physical, Cold Shock. It only takes 50% Damage from that type.

Chromatic Dragon.Monster Data: No tactic, mid HP, no gimmick

Passives.Same Roots:
All Twigs share the same HP pool.
For example, if you have 5 Twig Blights, they have a total of 50 HP.
Each time one of them takes Damage, deal Damage to that total HP pool.
Twigs won't die alone. When the total HP pool reaches 0, all Twigs die instantly.

Abilities.Shoot Spore Spike (15m):
The target rolls 1d4. Wild Fungus makes that many attacks.
Each attack deals 1d4 Scourge Damage.

Passives.Death Spores: On death, shoots one Spore Spike at the closest Unit.

Passives.Immunities: Immune to Poison and Scourge Damage.

Wild Fungus.Behavior: Acts as a regular mushroom until it detects danger.
Wild Fungus.Monster Data: No tactic, mid HP, no gimmick

Claws.Grab:
If rolled at least one 4 or 1, the target makes a Grade 11 Might or Dexterity Check (its choice).
On fail, the Harpy lifts the target, then flies with it with all remaining movement and drops it.

Passives.Charming Song: When the combat with Harpies starts, each player must succeed a 10 Sense Check or its Initiative is 0 this combat and become Fumbling (for 1 turn).

Passives.Mimick Song (Non-Combat): Harpies can mimick any song they have heard. Their voices can even reproduce sounds of instruments.

Harpy.Behavior:
Harpies ALWAYS try to fly away after an attack and consume all remaining movement.
Harpies will lure in prey with songs as they hide and ambush.
Try to have them sing uncononventional songs, like church music or
Harpy.Monster Data: No tactic, mid HP, no gimmick

Tongue Grab (3m).Drag and Stick:
Target must succeed a 12 Dexterity Check or the Mimic drags itself to it and sticks to it with its tongue.
If the Check fails, the Mimic can make a free Bite attack on the target.
The tongue remains attached to the target like glue.

Passives.Mimic Ambush: If someone approaches within 2 meters of the Mimic before combat, the combat starts and the Mimic gets Ambush Initiative.

Passives.Sticky:
Anything that touches the Mimic (weapons, objects, body parts), the owner must succeed a 10 Might Check remain stuck to the Mimic like glue.
Someone can use 0.5 Actions to try to unstick a single object or body part.
The Mimic can freely unstick itself from something (but will usually not do so unless they absolutely have to).
(Obviously, if your leg is stuck to the Mimic, you can't move; if your hand is stuck, you can't attack with it; and so on; use common sense)

Passives.Camouflage: When sitting still, it is indistinguishable from a regular chest, sofa, painting, etc.

Mimic.Behavior:
Waits patiently until someone comes within range to attack them.
A Mimic focuses attacks on a single target.
If not in Melee range, it uses Tongue Grab. Otherwise, it Bites.
Mimics fight to the death.
The Stickiness of the Mimic might prove a challenge for the players, as even after the Mimic dies, its tongue remains stuck to the target like glue. Same for anything that touched the Mimic.
Mimic.Lore:
Mimics are monsters that take the shape of common objects made of metal, wood or any household texture.
They can camouflage into any object it has seen that matches its volume.
Mimics come in all shapes and sizes. There could be a mimic the size of a bed morphed into a bed.
Mimics can also shapeshift into living creatures, albeit the form is rather crude and they can't move (the Mimic must remain still to maintain form).
Be creative with what the Mimic transforms into in order to ambush the Players!
Mimic.Monster Data: No tactic, mid HP, no gimmick
Mimic.Story Ideas:
Imagine this: a Mimic camouflages into a horse inside a dungeon.
Players can see skeletons and a backpack right near the horse.
The horse is obviously a mimic waiting for its prey.
However, the backpack/one of the skeletons is also a Mimic in disguise.
Add layers upon layers of disguise!
Mimic.Valuable Loot: Whatever non-digestible items the Mimic has eaten

Abilities.Dark Whispers:
All Units within 3 meters of the Gibbering Mouther must succeed a 11 Sense Check or take 10 Psychic Damage and Gibbering Mouther chooses one of these commands (separately for each) that the Unit must respect on its next turn:
- Move Away: use all movement to move in a straight line in whatever direction they choose (they stop at obstacles; can still move aftewards if they have movement left)
- Drop Weapon: drop their current weapon (or one of them); must use a Half-Action to pick it up again
- Silence: becomes Silenced

Passives.Only Eyes: Can not hear, but can see in all directions. Can see in darkness (even magical darkness).

Gibberer.Behavior:
Moves between as many enemies as possible. Doesn't care for Fumbling.
Use a different Dark Whispers effect every time.
Gibberer.Lore:
A Gibbering Mouther is an aberration creature that resembles an amorphous mass of flesh with eyes and mouths everywhere.
It has no ears, so it can not hear; it does, however, have eyes on all sides of its body.
Gibberer.Story Ideas:
Encounter idea: The inhabitants of a mansion seem to be going insane.
If there, the players can sometimes hear knocks and strange sounds coming from under the floor.
Of course, under no circumstance are the players allowed to go into the cellar by the mansion inhabitants.
If the players go into their cellar, they will find a dungeon with a Gibbering Mouther and a mad scientist living there.
How will they sneak in?

Spit (3m range).Spawn:
After this attack, the ooze loses half of its current HP.
Another Ooze is created near the target with that HP.
It starts its turn next round.

Passives.Acid Trail: Leaves Acid on the ground everywhere it moves. It deals 2 Damage when stepped on.

Passives.Corrosive: When hit with a metal weapon, that weapon permanently loses 1 Damage.

Passives.Immunities: Immune to Pierce, Poison and Acid Damage.

Passives.Camouflage (Non-Combat): Indistinguishable from a wet rock, puddle of oil, etc

Ooze.Behavior: Prefers to ambush by dropping from the ceiling, appearing from a sewer, etc.
Ooze.Monster Data: No tactic, mid HP, no gimmick
Ooze.Story Ideas: Players might get attacked by an Ooze coming out of a toilet or sewer.

Abilities.Blop (2m): Deal 1d8 Acid Damage to a Unit. Can only do this if nobody is Engulfed in it, but it would rather Sprint 4 meters.

Abilities.Digest (free): Deal 5 Acid Damage to all Units Engulfed inside (or 2d4).

Passives.Engulf:
When the Gelatinous Box walks into the space of another Medium or smaller Unit, it becomes Engulfed.
The Gelatinous Box will carry the Unit with it wherever it moves.
On its turn start, an Engulfed Unit takes 5 Poison Damage and is Slowed and Fumbling. It can use a Half-Action to exit the Gelatinous Box in a nearest space.
Multiple Units can be Engulfed.
Units pushed or falling into the Gelatinous Box also become Engulfed.

Gelatinous Box.Behavior:
Literaly walk over Units to automatically Engulf them.
Prefers to ambush by dropping from the ceiling, appearing from a sewer, etc.
Gelatinous Box.Lore:
Gelatinous Boxs are semi-transparent, ooze-like creatures made of bacteria.
Contrary to popular belief, they are not corrossive.
Gelatinous Box.Monster Data: No tactic, mid HP, no gimmick

Spell Block.Effect: When an enemy casts a Spell, the Spell is cancelled (Unit loses the Action and Mana for it). Then, the Mana Spawn dies (without triggering Detonation).

Passives.Detonation: When killed by Damage, the closest enemy of the Mana Spawn takes 1d4 Psychic Damage and must pass a Sense Check at least 10 or be Silenced.

Mana Spawn.Behavior:
Gets in your face and is annoying.
Will use Spell Block on first occasion.
Pair with spellcasters or Units such as Drow, Cultists, Cult Hierarchs or Liches.
Pair with demons for a spicy encounter (Cambions, Oni, etc).
Mana Spawn.Monster Data: No tactic, mid HP, no gimmick

Abilities.Attack Through: Fly 3 meters in a straight line. All Units hit take 1d6 Damage (Pierce, Slash or Smash).

Passives.Nimble: Can stay and move through spaces of other Units. Can perceive in the dark.

Passives.Immunities (Damage): Immune to Fire, Scourge, Poison, Psychic and Pierce Damage.

Flying Weapon.Behavior:
Attacks random targets.
Best paired with spell-oriented enemies.
Flying Weapon.Monster Data: No tactic, mid HP, no gimmick

Abilities.Melee Weapon: 8 and half (4) AoE around the target (or 1d6 + 4)

Passives.Crumbling Defense: Every time the Animated Armor is attacked (against Defense), it permanently loses 1 Defense (down to 0).

Passives.Resistances: Takes -50% Damage from Fire and Scourge.

Passives.Immunities: Immune to Psychic and Poison Damage and Fear, Charm and Sleep.

Passives.Autorepair (non-combat): Can stand still for 1 minute to restore 1 Defense.

Animated Armor.Pair: Pair with Flying Weapons that flank the Players.
Animated Armor.Story Ideas:
In an abandoned castle, 8 armor stands lay on either side of a corridor.
These armor stands do not activate.
However, if the players later return to the corridor, they will attack the players.
Alternatively, if the players decide to steal the armor stands, they will activate and start fighting later in the adventure, at the worst possible moment for the players.

Downslam.Area Slam: This hits all Units within 2 meters of the Gargoyle. Destroys all stone or wood obstacles hit, spreading debris.

Abilities.Wingdraw (5m):
Target a Unit.
Push away or pull (of choice) it and all other Medium or smaller Units within 2 meters of it in up to 3 meters.
They all take 1d4 + 4 Pulse Damage.

Abilities.Flame Breath:
All Units in a 90*, 4 meter long cone make a 10 Grade Dexterity Check.
On fail, they take 9 Fire Damage (or 3d4 + 1).
On success, they take half (4).

Passives.Searing Cracks: When the Gargoyle drops below 50% HP, blinding fire is emmited from its cracks. All Units that can see it must succeed a 12 Dexterity of Sense Check (of choice) or be Blinded.

Passives.Resistances: Takes -50% Fire, Shock and Psychic Damage.

Gargoyle.Behavior:
Gargoyles glide and try to position themselves to hit as many enemies as possible.
If they are pretending to be statues, it is hard for them to ambush the players, since they are large, heavy and hard to not notice.
Gargoyle.Pair: Pair with another Gargoyle for a deadly encounter.
Gargoyle.Lore:
Gargoyles are large statues with wings.
Unless they must fight, they will remain unmoving and indistinguishable from a regular statue.
Due to their heavy nature, their flight is limited.
They can glide, but they can't stay in the air for very long.

If you wish to have non-fire Gargoyles, 'reskin' Flame Breath to a large sweep attack, and Searing Cracks becomes a large gust of wind from its wings that Dazes instead of Blinds (regardless of whether Units see the Gargoyle or not).
Gargoyle.Monster Data: No tactic, mid HP, no gimmick
Gargoyle.Variants: Gargoyle (Smaller) - you can make a custom 300 XP Gargoyle with 60 HP, a speed of 6 and only one Action per turn. Feel free to use any of its Abilities in any order.
Gargoyle.Story Ideas:
While on their way to the mission, a group of adventurers approach an ominous building with two Gargoyle statues at its entrance.
Those two statues are actually just statues - the real Gargoyle is inside the building.
Or, simply have a Gargoyle attack the players before they enter the building - a separate Gargoyle, different from the regular statues.
They won't expect either of these scenarios!
Gargoyle.Valuable Loot: Gem Eyes (65g each), Magic Core Heart (200g) - used by Artificers to create golems

Passives.Rescramble:
When it dies, if there is another dead Skeleton within 6 meters, they magically fuse at the middle point.
A new Skeleton is created there. The 2 corpses disappear.
A player can deal any amount of Damage to the corpse to destroy it.

Passives.Immunities: Immune to Blind, Sleep and Psychic Damage; can perceive through darkness (even magical darkness).

Skeleton.Behavior:
A Skeleton battle can drag on a lot.
Make sure the players know there is a distance limit or they can destroy the corpses (or let them guess).
Skeleton.Monster Data: No tactic, mid HP, no gimmick

Passives.Undying: Can only be killed by a hit that deals at least 5 Damage (after Defense). Otherwise, the Zombie remains at 1 HP.

Passives.Corpse Burst: On death, all Units within 1 meter take 3 Poison Damage.

Passives.Immunities: Immune to Poison and Scourge Damage. Immune to difficult terrain.

Zombie.Behavior: Attack random targets. Zombies are some of the most basic of enemies.
Zombie.Monster Data: No tactic, mid HP, no gimmick

Abilities.Locust Curse:
Target a Unit and it becomes followed by locusts for 1 minute.
For each meter the Unit moves, it takes 1 True Damage (ignoring Defense).
Teleporting dissipates the locusts.

Passives.Hard and Slow: Immune to being Rooted, Slowed and to Hard Terrain.

Passives.Mummification Immunity: Immune to Damage from spells from the Eldritch and Nature schools.

Mummy.Monster Data: No tactic, mid HP, no gimmick
Mummy.Story Ideas:
A coven of druids or warlocks can't deal with the mummies because they're immune to their magic.
Also, you could trap the players inside a tomb with mummies chasing after them from outside just as they enter.

Passives.Resistances: Takes 50% Damage from all sources except True and Divine Damage.

Passives.Obscure: When within 2 meters of an enemy, the Wraith is completely invisible and can't be targeted (can still take Damage from AoE, DoT, etc). A Unit can make an attack in the air and roll a Grade 10 Luck Check to see if they actually hit by chance.

Wraith.Lore:
Wraiths a lot of the time are what people see in the corner of their eye, or maybe they appear at windows or in photographs.
Wraiths can only be seen from a distance, or if affected by spells like Fairy Fire or items like magic dust.
Wraith.Monster Data: No tactic, mid HP, no gimmick
Wraith.Story Ideas: The players are being haunted for several rooms or minutes until the Wraiths suddenly decide to attack. They can feel a presence...

Passives.Undead Fuel: +1 Damage for each fresh corpse in the battlefield

Passives.Scourge Aura: Living Units within 3 meters of a Ghoul can't recover Health.

Ghoul.Behavior: Ghouls try to run behind the tanks, but without provoking Oportunity Attacks.
Ghoul.Pair:
Pair with Skeletons only if your players are really strong.
For a difficult encounter, pair with Zombies.
Ghoul.Lore: Ghouls like to dig corpses and eat flesh.
Ghoul.Monster Data: No tactic, mid HP, no gimmick
Ghoul.Story Ideas:
Players might receive a quest about some corpse smuggling bandits.
They catch the bandits with corpses, and half-way through the combat, they are all attacked by Ghouls.
Will they work with the bandits to survive?

Huge Claws (2m).Effect: Deals extra Damage equal to the the target's missing Mana points

Passives.Aura of Decay: Units that can see or hear a Wight have their Sense and Charisma (the actual Stat) set to 0 (if it's more than 0).

Wight.Behavior: Tries to hit Player Characters that have low Mana.
Wight.Monster Data: No tactic, mid HP, no gimmick
Wight.Story Ideas: Have an encounter with Wights in the middle of a day of adventuring. Too early might make the players retired, and too late might kill them.

Abilities.Flare:
All living Units within 3 meters must succeed a 10 Sense Check or take 25% of their current HP as Scourge Damage.
After this, the Will-o-Wisp dies.

Passives.Fear Sight: The first time someone sees a Will-o-Wisp, they must succeed a 11 Sense Check or take 25% of their current HP as Scourge Damage or be Feared. The same target can't be affected by the Fear Sight again for 24 hours (but can be affected by Flare).

Passives.Dimming: Will-o-Wisp can dim the light they emmit by up to 80% to become stealthy. Increase a Grade for noticing the Will-o-Wisp out of combat by 5.

Will-o-Wisp.Behavior:
Will-o-Wisps slowly approach targets and detonate as soon as they can hit at least one target.
They might hide in trees, tall grass, fields, etc.
Will-o-Wisp.Lore:
Will-o-Wisps are undead spirits of death.
Rumors say that if you see a Will-o-Wisp, that warns about someone's death - for you or for someone close to you.
Suggested Obstacles: Open fields, closed off by obstacles

Abilities.Claws (x1/x2/...): Make a number of Claws attacks for 1d6 + 1 Slash each equal to the round number (x1, x2, x3, etc).

Abilities.The Eyes (free) (once): A Unit that can see the Strigoi must succeed a Sense Check or be Charmed.

Passives.Semi-Undeath: When the Strigoi drops to 0 Health, it can still make its next turn and is immune to Damage until then. After its next turn, it dies.

Passives.Silver Fearer: Takes +50% Damage from attacks weapons coated in garlic tincture or silver.

Strigoi.Monster Data: No tactic, mid HP, no gimmick

Passives.Lifesteal: If not affected by Crowd Control, the Edimmara heals for all the Damage it lands on attacks (before reductions).

Passives.Infinite Reactions: Has unlimited Reactions (for Retaliation and Opportunity Attacks).

Passives.Retaliation: After a Unit affects the Edimmara in any way, if it's within 5 meters of it, the Edimmara runs towards that Unit and attacks it at 2 meters range.

Passives.Opportunity Attacks: When a Unit Flees from the Edimmara, the Edimmara can make a free attack on it.

Passives.Immunities: Immune to Blind and Hard Terrain.

Passives.Vulnerabilities: Damage with garlic tincture and silver can't be healed and make the Edimmara Fumbling until the end of its next turn (which counts as Crowd Control, so it prevents healing).

Edimmara.Behavior: Gets in the middle of the fight and tries to attack everyone with its Retaliation.
Edimmara.Monster Data: No tactic, mid HP, no gimmick
Edimmara.Story Ideas:
Have the players make a Luck Check to see if they by any chance have some garlic in their rations.
Note that Edimmara can be very strong against low level parties, and it is recommended that you allow Intelligence Checks for the players to determine if they know what an Edimmara does and how to combat it (Crowd Control, garlic and silver).

Abilities.Eldritch Eater (Reaction) (once per roun: Whenever a Unit casts a Divine Spell or a Cleric or Paladin Class Spell (not Passives), the Ghast also heals one of its other allies for 15.

Passives.Mist: Emmits a Mist within 3 meters around. Its allies inside the mist are immune to Crowd Control and have Cover to actions from outside.

Passives.Resistances: Takes -50% Damage except True and Divine Damage.

Ghast.Behavior:
Ghasts will try to stay near its allies.
Always use Eldritch Eater when possible (but only once per round).
A successful Intelligence Check will tell players that the mist makes the dead unrestrainable and restless, or that Ghasts are known to eat Eldritch or Restorative spells.
Ghast.Lore:
Ghasts are large ghosts of sadness created from a conglomeration of sad souls who could not transcend to the other side.
Some say Ghasts are formed on burial grounds of people who died a sad death from the same cause and were not mourned.
Ghast.Story Ideas:
There's a quest to clear an old uninhabited village of possible scavengers to make it live-able again.
A Ghast formed at the remains of a ruined house, where an empoverished family died inside of starvation.
The same person who sent the Players failed to distribute food among the population of that village.
It could be that this person was a livery of supplies for this village, but chose to keep and sell the supplies instead.

Abilities.Nice Try: Stop looking up monsters! That's cheating!

Passives.Blurry Focus: All enemies that can see or hear the Bou-Bou have the range of all Abilities and attacks halved if they are looking at the Monsters page CLICK BACK.

Bou-Bou.Lore:
Bou-Bou is a mix between a giant undead shadow fiend. Its presence instills fear and its eyes induce blurry vision.
The Bou-Bou originates from the Berber mythology.
Bou-Bou.Monster Data: No tactic, mid HP, no gimmick

Abilities.Death Cloud (10m to edge):
Declare a 5x5 meter area.
Deal Scourge Damage to all non-undead Units caught equal to 1d6 + number of Units caught in the area (ignores Cover).
A cloud of Scourge Gas (Toxic Gas) forms there and remains for 1 minute. Enemies are Silenced while inside the gas.

Abilities.Summon Skeletons: Summon a skeleton in a chosen space near every enemy. Skeletons have 1 Health and 4 Speed, and can attack for 1d4 Damage (Slash/Pierce/Smash). They have 0 Initiative.

Abilities.Soul Bolts (10m): Shoot (2) Soul Bolts at random enemies, each dealing 1d4 True Damage (directly, ignoring Defense). Next cast shoots 1 more bolt than the previous (e.g round 1 - 2 bolts, round 2 - 3 bolts, round 3 - 4 bolts, etc).

Abilities.Asphyxiate (10m): Up to 3 Units must make a Sense Check or take 1d6 + 3 Pulse Damage (or half on pass) and be Crowd Controlled. Roll 1d4 (once) for the CC type - 1. Dazed, 2. Fumbling, 3. Sleep, 4. Feared.

Passives.Finger of Death (Reaction) (10m): When a Unit takes Damage and is at or below 33% Health, shoot a death ray for 8 Damage towards it (against Defense) (or 3d4).

Passives.Teleportation: When the Lich moves, it teleports to the destination within Movement (if not Silenced). Alternatively, it can fly  (if not Silenced).

Passives.Resistances: Takes -50% Psychic, Scourge and Poison Damage.

Passives.Spellcasting (non-combat): Can cast miscelaneous spells like Light, Bonfire, etc.

Passives.Phylactery (non-combat): Every lich has its soul stored inside an item called a phylactery. When the lich dies, its soul is transported into the phylactery. Someone else can conduct a ritual to bring the lich back to life and materialize it outside the phylactery.

Lich.Behavior:
Uses Finger of Death on the first Player Character that drops to or below 33% Health.
Teleport to take advantage of terrain and avoid Cover on Soul Bolts. Choose targets for Soul Bolts pseudo-randomly (e.g. just pick enemies in such a way that it looks random, or roll dice).
Hit as many Units as possible (even allies) with Death Cloud.
Avoid repeat-casting Finger of Death on the same Unit - hold it for other Units. Note that it's a Reaction, and can't be used on the Lich's own turn.
Pair with a Flying Weapon, a Gasha, Bat Swarms, Zombies and Cultists.
Avoid pairing with normal Skeletons to prevent confusion.
Make the Lich a 1200 Experience Epic x4 monster by increasing its Health to 250 and Defense to 4.
Lich.Monster Data: No tactic, mid HP, no gimmick

Passives.Impenetrable Bones: Takes no Damage from missiles (e.g. arrows, Magic Missiles, Flamebolt, etc).

Passives.Materialize: For 0 Actions, the Gasha can turn into smoke and ash and disappear, teleport or appear (if not Silenced). How, when and why they do this is unknown, though a lot of the time a strange ringing noise can be heard before one appearing.

Passives.Resistances: Takes -50% Scourge, Fire, Poison and Pierce Damage.

Passives.Immunities: Immune to Hard Terrain, Fumbling, Fear and Charm.

Gasha.Behavior:
The Gasha appears out of nowhere, looking to kill.
If your fight with other monsters is too easy, make a Gasha appear out of nowhere.
If below 20 Health or if it can't chase players, the Gasha might choose to disappear on its turn. It might appear later.
Turn the Gasha into a smaller 250 Experience one by halving its Health (100) and making its Smash deal 1d8 + 4 instead.
Gasha.Monster Data: No tactic, mid HP, no gimmick
Gasha.Story Ideas:
Players fight a Gasha. The first round goes well, until, out of nowhere, another Gasha appears. The players will struggle, but just as they think they got it, look them dead in the eye and tell them a third Gasha appears out of nowhere.
If the players ever try to "cheese" or "cheat" a Gasha fight, make it disappear. Then it will appear again at the worst possible moment for the players.

Embottle Magic.Effect: After a Unit finishes using an Ability that costs Mana, the Imp can Silence it.

Passives.Camouflage: Has Cover when near a wall or Large obstacle.

Imp.Behavior:
Do not prioritize staying near walls and just chase whoever has the most mana.
Make Imps a 150 Experience monster by increasing its Health by 10, and Bite Damage to 1d6 + 2
Imp.Monster Data: No tactic, mid HP, no gimmick

Abilities.Possess Corpse (once):
The Kasu removes the head of a dead Unit and enroots its spine inside of it, with its own head as the new head.
Infused with demonic energy, that Unit becomes alive again, with its normal stats and full Health.
If this one dies, the Kasu dies too.
Apply common sense to whether a corpse is possessable (e.g. golems and destroyed corpses are probably not).

Kasu.Behavior:
In combat, the Kasu will hang out in the back and avoid Damage, but stay in range of other monsters.
If there is any corpse around, it will possess it.
It bites only if it can't possess and is threatened.
Out of combat, Kasu usually kill and possess human corpses and walk among people. Upon disected, a human body being possessed by a Kasu will have twice the number of inner organs, a set of each is rotting, but kept odor-free by being tightly sealed inside the body.
Kasu.Monster Data: No tactic, mid HP, no gimmick

Fangs.Strangle: On 5, 6, 7 and 8, target must succeed a Grade 10 Might Check or be Fumbling and Slowed.

Passives.Minus 3 Defense: Takes 2 extra damage from all sources.

Moroy.Behavior: Note the negative Defense - Moroy are fleshy and easy to hit
Moroy.Lore: A Moroy (or Drekavac) is a baby that died early and was affected by demonic presences - thus, it is both a demon and an undead.
Moroy.Monster Data: No tactic, mid HP, no gimmick
Moroy.Story Ideas: Players must investigate an abandoned maternity. Why was it abandoned? What do they find inside?

Abilities.Charge... (15m): Prepare a shot on a Unit and lock onto it, seeing it through walls. Next turn, the first thing the Flame Skull does is Fire!

Abilities.Fire! (15m): Shoot that Unit for 10 Fire Damage (or 4d4). Walls block the attack, but the impact is strong enough to break many walls and obstacles.

Passives.Resistances: Takes -50% Pierce, Psychic and Fire Damage.

Flame Skull.Behavior: Pair with other types of demons, like Imps and Cambions.
Flame Skull.Monster Data: No tactic, mid HP, no gimmick

Abilities.Curse of Weakness: Curse a Unit. It becomes Fumbling. Does not work on Paladins.

Abilities.Curse of Agony: Choose a Unit the Likho can see. Next time it takes Damage from one of its enemies, it is doubled (all after Defense). Lasts for 1 minute.

Passives.Return Crowd Control: Immune to Crowd Control. When targeted by a Crowd Control Ability, the cast is redirected towards a Unit of Likho's choice if the chosen target is valid (e.g. is within Range).

Passives.Bad Luck: All Player Characters within 1km of a Likho have -5 Luck (secretly or not).

Likho.Behavior:
Likho might stalk the players for a while, not engaging in combat.
Although demonic, Likho do not originate in hell, but have unknown origins and a lot of the time live in forests or near villages, as they feed on bad luck.
Pair with Twig Blights, Wild Fungi or golems.
Pairing with Will-o-Wisps will make an encounter very spicy.
Likho.Monster Data: No tactic, mid HP, no gimmick

Trident (2m).Burst: If rolled 1 or 6, target must succeed a Might Check or become Maimed. A Maimed Player Character can only make Half-Actions, but not full Actions.

Passives.Flame Burst: When the Cambion takes Damage, deal 2 Fire Damage to all non-Cambion Units within 3 meters (directly, ignoring Defense).

Passives.Flame Ray (Reaction): When a Unit exits Cambion's 5 meter range area, make a free attack on that Unit for 1d8 Fire Damage. That Unit can't be targeted by another Flame Ray until the end of its turn.

Cambion.Behavior:
Goes head-first into as many enemies as possible, to hit as many as it can with Flame Burst and make them run away so it can do a Flame Ray.
Note that two or more Cambions won't make a Flame Ray attack on the same Unit on the same turn.
Pair with any Hell Hounds and any demons.
Cambion.Lore: Cambions are person, sentient demons from hell. Although they can speak and rationalize, Cambions are fundamentally driven by the will of their creator or demon patron - it is their innate will to follow the doctrine of their hierarch.
Suggested Obstacles: Fire that errupts randomly when combat starts
Cambion.Monster Data: No tactic, mid HP, no gimmick

Sword Quake (2m).Cracks: A 5x5 area centered on the target becomes Hard Terrain due to cracks on the ground.

Abilities.Drain Soul (5m):
A Unit must succeed a Grade 11 Sense Check or choose: take 6d4 True Damage or roll 1d4 and permanently have -1 to all Checks for: 1. Sight, 2. Hearing, 3. Smell, 4. Luck.
This can never be cured. The player must decide before rolling the dice.

Abilities.Gauze of Death (5m):
Two Units become affected by the Gauze of Death.
At the end of their next turn, they take 3d4 + 4 Scourge Damage unless they were healed for at least 1 Health until then.

Passives.Magic: Can cast small utility Spells like Light, Magic Tricks, etc.

Oni.Behavior:
Let the players know they have a choice between heavy Damage and permanent sanity loss.
In-game, the character goes through a heavy mental struggle and feels as if their soul is being ripped apart.
Turn the Oni into an 825 Experience Epic x3 monster by increasing its health to 265.
Oni.Monster Data: No tactic, mid HP, no gimmick
Oni.Valuable Loot: Oni use Greatswords (normally selling for 325g), though the sword might be Damaged further. Oni might also carry items such as simple jewelry, alcohol or stolen religious symbols.

Spine Whip (3m).Effect: For each 1 and 4 rolled, applies (1) Bleed to the target for its next turn. On its next turn, every time it does anything, it takes Damage equal to its Bleed (directly, ignoring Defense).

Passives.Runner: After every time it takes Damage, it can freely move up to 2 meters.

Nuckelavee.Monster Data: No tactic, mid HP, no gimmick

Abilities.Hell's Chase (free): Once per turn, the Dullahan can teleport 3 meters. If any enemy Units were near it before teleporting, they all must succeed a Dexterity Check or take 1d6 direct Fire Damage be Fumbling.

Passives.Death Strike: If the Dullahan took Damage 3 or more times this Round, its first attack every turn deals 17 Damage (instead of 11).

Passives.Immunities: Immune to Psychic Damage and to being Blinded and Feared (you know, because they have no head).

Dullahan.Behavior:
If there's an enemy near it, teleports away before attacking another Unit.
Try to spread the Damage evenly among Player Characters - Dullahan don't care about who is the biggest threat. They are also smart enough to Flank and
Dullahan.Monster Data: No tactic, mid HP, no gimmick
Dullahan.Valuable Loot: Dullahan might drop their armors (Scale Mails, usually) and weapons (Sickle, usually).

Fist Smash (3m).Effect: If target is Medium or smaller, it is pushed 5 meters in any direction (Chernobog chooses).

Abilities.Flame Waves (20m): All Units within exactly an even number of meters from the Chernobog take 1d10 + 11 Fire Damage.

Abilities.Soul Lock: Two Units that can see the Chernobog must make a Grade 13 Sense Check or take 11 Scourge Damage, are Charmed and can never use the last Basic Ability they used (ever).

Abilities.Fire Ball (10m to edge): All Units in a 6x6x6 meter area take 6d6 Fire Damage.

Passives.Act or Die: After the end of every enemy's turn, if it didn't do Damage to the Chernobog, they take 1d10 + 5 Psychic Damage and are Dazed.

Passives.Hell Fissure: When reaching 50% or less Health, the Chernobog creates a gigantic fissure in the ground, underneat all enemies. This fissure is a gateway to a delimited part of hell, and everyone falls inside. Demons might await or emerge from the fissure. The fissure is isolated from the rest of the hell. The fissure closes 10 minutes after the Chernobog dies. Anyone still inside remain trapped that part of hell.

Chernobog.Monster Data: No tactic, mid HP, no gimmick

Passives.Sandstorm:
When Sandman is revealed (or whenever it wants), it creates a 4x4 sand storm at its location (free Action).
The sand storm is difficult terrain.
Attacks in, out and through the sand storm have Cover.
A storm can be dissipated with large wind/force gusts or other creative means.

Passives.Sandstorm Invisibility:
While inside a sand storm, Sandman is invisible, inaudible and immune to opportunity attacks.
Sandman is unaffected by the negative effects of the sand storm.

Passives.Partial Invisibility (Non-Combat): Invisible out of combat. Revealed when a different creature gets close (1 meter).

Passives.Steal Sleep (Non-Combat):
If a Sandman is nearby (5 meters) when someone is sleeping, their sleep becomes low quality sleep.
If players sleep with Sandmen nearby, it counts as if they didn't sleep at all.

Sandman.Behavior:
Do not reveal the position of a Sandman until it's no longer in a storm.
Secretly keep in mind the position of a Sandman.
Sandmen typically roam in groups.
They will silently climb onto windows and drain the sleep of someone.
Sandman.Lore:
Sandmen are small, yet powerful fiends that steal quality sleep.
While someone is sleeping, the Sandman can feed on its sleep.
This does not wake up their victims or reveal the Sandman.
This also often results in sleep paralysis, nightmares or waking up more tired than before.
Sandman.Story Ideas: In a town, somewhere, someone believes they are cursed with insomnia by a witch/his enemy. Turns out, multiple people are affected, and it was just a Sandman infestation.

Scourge Touch.Strength Wither:
Put one Wither token on the target.
At 3 Wither tokens, the target permanently loses 1 in a Stat Check of choice (e.g. Sense, Might, etc) (note: not in the Stat itself, but only Checks with that Stat).
Then remove the tokens.

Passives.Immunities: Immune to all Damage except True and Divine Damage.

Passives.Shadowy: Indistinguishable from a regular shadow. Can freely walk on or attach to any surface, but can't jump. Light does not affect it. They occupy a space on the battlefield as normal.

Shadow.Behavior:
Hides.
If revealed, it usually tries to run and hide.
Prefers to avoid combat and only fights if attacked.
If it fights, it fights to the death, but is territorial.
Does not usually chase, but will kill if it has to.
Shadow.Lore: Shadows usually haunt locations and smart people with active minds struck by anxiety, depression, etc.
Shadow.Monster Data: No tactic, mid HP, no gimmick
Shadow.Story Ideas: Here's an idea to introduce Shadows - someone is very worried about something mundane - their wife cheating, guards being after him, etc. In reality, this is not true and the person is just very paranoid. Turns out the paranoia is caused by a Shadow haunting.

Abilities.Spirit Seep:
Attack up to 3 Units within 3 meters for 6 Scourge Damage (or 2d4 + 1).
They are Slowed.

Abilities.Scare Around (Free) (once per combat):
All Units within 3 meters of the Bubak must succeed a 12 Sense Check or be Dazed.
The Bubak casts Scare Around on its first turn of combat for free.

Passives.Dormant:
While possessing a scarecrow and out of combat, the Bubak is dormant and inactive (the scarecrow is just a scarecrow).
If the Bubak is attacked while dormant (e.g. from far away), it will just swap to a different Scarecrow with Body Swap.
The Damage to the scarecrow does not affect the HP of the Bubak.

Passives.Body Swap (Non-Combat): While the Bubak is dormant, it can choose to instantly swap the scarecrow it is possessing to another one within 15 meters. It can do this at any point while dormant. If there is no scarecrow to swap to, the Bubak dies.

Passives.Scare:
When someone comes within 3 meters of the Bubak, it becomes Active.
It teleports near the target (up to 3 meters) and the targets are Ambushed.
All other Bubaks in the area do the same.

Passives.Consume Body: The Bubak can consume a dead body to fuel itself. The body disappears.

Bubak.Behavior:
Bubaks live inside scarecrows.
They do not become active even when attacked from a distance.
If the players would destroy from a distance a scarecrow where the Bubak is, the Bubak just swaps body to another nearby scarecrow.
It immediately attacks as soon as someone gets close enough or if there is no other scarecrow to swap to.
Bubak.Lore:
A Bubak is a spirit that inhabits scarecrows.
When dormant, it is impossible to detect a Bubak inside a scarecrow (except through magical means).
When active, the Bubak has the body of a scarecrow but is covered in an ominous aura of any color that inspires evil or fear.
Suggested Obstacles: Oil Lamps with flammable materials around
Bubak.Monster Data: No tactic, mid HP, no gimmick

Abilities.Distort Area (10m):
Distort matter in a 3x3 meter area. All Units there take 13 Damage (or 1d8 + 9).
All non-Unit matter remains distorted, even floating in the air.

Abilities.Gravitate: Each Unit within 15 meters takes Pulse Damage equal to its distance to the Singularity, then is pulled 3 up to meters towards it.

Passives.Time Distorsion: Every Unit takes its turns twice, including the Singularity (so it takes 4 turns total). You should make sure Players understand the danger that's coming.

Passives.Warp Effect: At the start of every Unit's turn (except the Singularity), it chooses whether to be instantly Rooted, Crippled, Silenced or Stunned. It can't choose the same thing again until it has chosen each once (then repeat).

Passives.MC-like Levitation: Things put in the air remain floating in the air until moved.

Passives.Flyer and Teleporter: Flies. Can teleport instead of moving.

Singularity.Behavior:
A Singularity is a strange, sentient phenomenon whose only purpose is to destroy, for unknown reasons.
It appears to have glimpses of extreme intelligence, and glimpses of very low (e.g. one time it might choose to position itself to hit well with Gravitate, other times not).
Suggested Obstacles: Trees, rocks, obstacles that can be permanently distorted
Explosive barrels (the gunpowder remains floating in the air)
Caltrops (they remain floating in the air)
Singularity.Monster Data: No tactic, mid HP, no gimmick
Singularity.Story Ideas: Strange distorsions are seen throughout an area or at a distance. What could be causing them?

Abilities.Dazzling Wave:
Create a 20x1x2 meter wall of light that can move 3 meters at the start of Seraph's every turn.
Enemies passing through it must make a Might Check or take 9 direct Divine Damage and are Dazed and Slowed (or half) until their next turn.
They do not provide cover and can be jumped.

Abilities.Rays:
Players choose 2 targets for this attack (not necessraily knowing what will happen).
The 2 Units must succeed 11 Grade a Charisma check or be Slowed and Blinded and take 7 Divine Damage (or half).
They must choose the next 2 targets. Only one can be the same.

Abilities.Lightspawns:
Summon 1d4 flying orbs near the Seraph each that will target a different enemy.
Orbs have only 1 Health, 2 Defense, and have 3 meters speed.
Each orb chases one player. Upon collision, it explodes and damages it for 12 Damage.

Abilities.Feather Barrage:
Attack all Units in a 4x4 area for 2d6 Pierce Damage.
Forms a "[" of caltrops on the ground, towards the Seraph.

Passives.Futility: After someone makes an attack with a weapon or uses an Ability, it can't be used anymore for the rest of the combat. Weapons vanish into thin air and Abilities are forgotten. Improvised Attack counts as 3 separate Abilities (Small, Medium and Large).

Seraph.Monster Data: No tactic, mid HP, no gimmick

Summon Undead.Effect: Summon a number of Zombies equal to 1 + current Round number, anywhere on the map. Zombies have 1d6 + 3 Damage, Corpse Burst, and can do Opportunity Attacks.

Frost Breath.Effect: Breathe cold in a CROSS centered on a Unit, dealing 2d6 Cold Damage and Slowing them. All further Cold Damage they take increases by 25%.

Wyvern Poison (2m).Effect: Bite a Unit for 3d6 Poison Damage. They must make a Might Check or be Dazed. At the end of its turn, the poison passes to a nearby ally within 3 meters (once).

Abilities.Dominate: 3 Units must make a Sense Check or be Crippled and each take 6 True Damage.

Passives.Summon More Undead: Whenever someone spends Mana, raise one Icy Skeleton near it - it has 5 Health, 0 Defense, 4 Speed and can attack for 1d6 Cold Damage.

Passives.Retaliate: The first time hit ranged from 5 or less meters away, flies to the target and does a Wyvern Poison attack.

KingBolgurWithWyvern.Monster Data: No tactic, mid HP, no gimmick

Summon Undead (Free).Effect: Summon a number of Zombies equal to 1 + current Round number, anywhere on the map. Icy Zombies have 1d6 + 3 Damage, Corpse Burst, and can do Opportunity Attacks.

Frost Pillars (Free).Effect: Summon 2 Frost Pillars with 10 Health. All non-undead Units within 2 meters of them are Slowed and take 50% more Cold Damage.

Cleave.Effect: Deal 4d6 Slash Damage to a Unit, and half of that as COLD to all Units within 2 meters. The Primary target takes 25% more Cold Damage.

Frosthold.Effect: All Units in a 3x3 area must succeed a Grade 12 Dexterity Check or be Snared and take 8 Cold Damage (or half). All further Cold Damage they take is increased by 25%.

Passives.Cold Regeneration: Heals all the Cold Damage anyone else does.

KingBolgur.Monster Data: No tactic, mid HP, no gimmick
